postsData.content:
A common problem for coaches: 
 
They get a new client and work with them for a short time ... often 3 months.

After 3 months the coaching relationship ends, and the coach has to find another client to replace the one that's moving on.

It becomes a treadmill for the coach to try to stay full!

has perfected a system of running masterminds, where you keep your people for 3 years (or more) instead of just 3 months, meaning you can get off that treadmill and make more money while working a lot less.

He's going to show how you can do it in a live masterclass that he's doing next Tuesday - save your seat for it in the comments!

postsData.name:
Ani Filipova
Ani Filipova
postsData.content:
A CV tells you what someone has done.
It doesn't tell you who they are.

Businesses keep hiring the wrong people - then wonder why their teams lack accountability and drive.

The person with the right skills but the wrong attitude?
They'll ruin your culture.
The person with the right attitude but the wrong skills?
They'll learn, adapt, and outperform everyone.

Hiring needs a revamp.
Too many businesses obsess over:

 Fancy CVs
 AI-driven screenings
 Box-ticking qualifications

But the truth is:
 Skills can be taught.
 Character cannot.

You can't train reliability.
You can't coach integrity.
You can't teach ownership.

As a small company, I never start from the CV.
I want to see how someone works, their values, and their attitude first.

For corporations, this is harder - but not impossible.
And if your success depends on people, not just AI and robots, isn't it worth fixing?

What is the best possible hiring practice you have seen work?

 Repost this to challenge outdated hiring practices and followfor more content like this.

Image credit: heatherleigh on Pinterest

comments.commentText: I agree Ani Filipova. Hiring should start with values and attitude first, because the right character shapes culture and fuels long-term success, beyond any qualifications or AI filters.

postsData.content:
Case Study: BTC Magazine App Launch in 3 Months! 

We had the incredible opportunity to partner with BTC Magazine to create an app that elevates the way readers engage with Bitcoin content. 

Challenge Accepted:

BTC Magazine needed a dynamic app ready to launch at their annual BTC conference - and they gave us just 3 months! ⏳

Our Solution:
 Developed a user-friendly app for reading blogs, listening to podcasts, and consuming media.

 Integrated features for users to Read, Learn, and Earn Bitcoin while engaging with the content. 

 Ensured a seamless and immersive experience for all Bitcoin enthusiasts. 

The Result:
We successfully launched the BTC Magazine app on time, providing an innovative platform for their audience just in time for the conference. The feedback was overwhelmingly positive! 

Key Takeaways:
 Tight deadlines fuel creativity and innovation.
 Collaboration and communication are crucial.
 Focus on user experience ensures success.

postsData.name:
Natalia Cano
Natalia Cano
postsData.content:
7 things NOT TO DO when job hunting

(and what to do instead):

1. Applying for every job you remotely qualify for
Swap:
↳ Spreading yourself too thin and diluting your efforts
With:
↳ Using your values and strengths as the guiding star

2. Obsessing about everyone in the hiring process
Swap:
↳ Sending connection requests before interviewing
With:
↳ Maintaining a professional online presence

3. The ‘One Size Fits All’ approach
Swap:
↳ Submitting a generic resume with buzz words
With:
↳ A bespoke application to each specific job

4. Becoming a future fortune teller
Swap:
↳ Focusing too much on your long-term career goals
With:
↳ Linking your aspirations to the current role

5. Waiting for the "perfect" opportunity
Swap:
↳ Spending excessive time perfecting your resume
With:
↳ Action. Done is better than perfect. Speed matters

6. Failing to engage
Swap:
↳ Coldness and too much seriousness
With:
↳ Enthusiasm and a genuine smile

7. Acting like a robot
Swap:
↳ Memorizing answers to common questions
With:
↳ Letting your personality and passion shine through

Which one resonates with you?

Let me know below 

p.s.

Do you want to get 3X More Job Interviews?

Download my free Fill-in-the-Blank Resume Template:



‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾
️ Repost this to help others master their job hunt
 Followfor daily content like this

If your ideas aren't gaining traction, start engaging stakeholders early.

Understand their goals and priorities and align your proposal.

Don't just align - co-create with them.

When people build together, they fight to make it succeed.

The more buy-in you build, the more your ideas will succeed.

Which means greater impact and recognition.

Influence starts with engagement.

PS: The hardest part? Letting the idea outgrow your ego.

postsData.content:
Coffee with Dharm: Revolutionizing Talent – Preparing the Workforce for AI-Driven Mobility

"Revolutionizing Talent Strategies for the Smart Mobility Era – Insights Powered by Nalanda Institute of Technology, Bhubaneswar"
 As part of the HR Conclave 2025: A.C.E., the session “Coffee with Dharm” offered an engaging and intimate platform for thought-provoking insights into reshaping workforce strategies in the age of AI-driven mobility.
Session Details:
 Date: 1st February 2025
⏰ Time: 5:00 PM - 5:30 PM
 Venue: Hilton DoubleTree, Sec-56, Golf Course Road, Gurgaon
Keynote Speaker:
 Dharm Rakshit
Head HR & President, NHRD Rewari-Alwar Chapter, Hero Motors
Renowned Auto Industry Expert
Board Member, Mentor, Professor of Practice
Moderator:
️ Arun Malhotra
Auto Industry Visionary
Former Managing Director, Nissan India
Highlights of the Discussion:
 AI-Driven Talent Evolution: Dharm Rakshit emphasized the importance of preparing the workforce for AI-enabled ecosystems by integrating technology-driven processes with human expertise.
 Strategic Workforce Transformation: The session delved into strategies for upskilling and reskilling talent, enabling employees to adapt to the rapidly evolving mobility and manufacturing sectors.
 Bridging the Skills Gap: Both Dharm and Arun highlighted the need for collaborative efforts between academia and industry, creating talent pipelines equipped with future-ready skills to thrive in AI-driven mobility ecosystems.
 Leadership in Change: The session underscored the critical role of leadership and mentorship in driving workforce transformation, empowering employees to stay resilient and innovative in an ever-changing environment.
This fireside chat resonated with the audience as it provided practical strategies and a visionary approach to tackling the challenges posed by AI in workforce management and mobility innovations.

postsData.name:
Software/Technology: AI, Marketing, Social Media, Startups, Blockchain, Human Resources & Metaverse
Software/Technology: AI, Marketing, Social Media, Startups, Blockchain, Human Resources & Metaverse
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 5 – CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today’s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.

postsData.name:
Victoria Repa
Victoria Repa
postsData.content:
Not everyone has the luxury to quit.

Some stay because they need the job.

But here’s what happens when a workplace turns toxic:

 Innovation dies:
fear replaces creativity.

 People stop sharing ideas:
it’s just not worth the risk.

 The “bare minimum” becomes the norm:
why go the extra mile if no one cares?

Top talent doesn’t always quit immediately.

Some leave at the first sign of a toxic culture.

Others stay — but with one foot out the door,
always checking for better opportunities.

A paycheck might keep people in the office.

But a healthy culture makes them show up with passion. 

️ Share if you agree.
️ And followfor more.

comments.commentText: Great insight Victoria Repa A toxic workplace loses people long before they leave, draining innovation and drive. A paycheck keeps them there, but culture keeps them engaged.

Why a Job Alone Won’t Make You Financially Secure 

Whether you're working 70 or 90 hours a week, relying solely on your job won’t guarantee financial freedom. The key to long-term wealth lies in strategic savings and investments.

One lesson I wish I learned earlier in my career? Diversify your investments. 

 Last year, both the NIFTY50 and Sensex delivered just 5.9% and 5.4% returns in USD terms—barely outperforming a bank FD. Meanwhile, the US markets (driven by tech, AI, and semiconductors) saw impressive returns of 29% (Nasdaq) and 23.3% (S&P 500)!

This sharp contrast shows how crucial global diversification is to building wealth.

 Why is this important right now?
With the USD at an all-time high of 86.65 vs the INR, it’s a good time to protect your portfolio from INR depreciation and leverage the USD’s growth.

 If you're wondering how to tap into global opportunities, platforms like Vested Finance make it seamless to create a diversified portfolio with access to over 10,000 US Stocks & ETFs.

Don't just rely on local markets—start building a truly global portfolio today! 

You should definitely check it out :
Explore Vested to diversify your investments and get a $10 bonus by signing up:

postsData.content:
Layoffs aren't all bad



Hear me out:

When the majority of my clients who've been laid off say something like:

1// It was time for me to move on

2// I'd been in a rut, ready to go but needed a push

3// The company didn't align with my values anymore

>> I'm leaning in to listen <<


The truth is, you're meant to have a fulfilling career.

1// not to settle ... or go ho hum into the night

2// somewhere you can grow in the direction you choose

3// a place that you feel valued and that values you in return


So how about this:
What if you let your layoff inspire you?

1// try a new approach

2// reconnect with your purpose

3// reach out to people and resources that can help


You might just be surprised
at how much your layoff
is part of your story
and will fuel you.

Use it.

 And the way you bounce back from it and grow?

Now that is your next big story.
Let's make it epic.

And DM me if you need help.






Grateful for people like this who invest in themselves after a layoff and come back with a NEW HIGH SCORE, NEXT LEVEL UNLOCKED, THRILL RIDE of a career move.

It's an honor to be a part of your story.

postsData.name:
Mark R. Koesterer
Mark R. Koesterer
postsData.content:
Jeff, I appreciate your insights on the challenges surrounding consultants and solution providers in the NIL era. Your perspective highlights a critical issue—the need for genuine value beyond relationships, especially in such a fast-evolving landscape.

While much of the current conversation is centered around the "hot topics" of NIL collective payments, transfer portals, and pay-for-play models—issues that primarily impact the top 2% of college athletes—I believe we're overlooking a significant opportunity. I focus on 98% of student-athletes who aren't navigating million-dollar deals or eyeing professional sports careers. These athletes represent the heart of college athletics, and their needs extend far beyond the transactional nature of NIL.

What if we shifted the narrative? Instead of reacting to the chaos, let's proactively support these athletes through life skills, personal development, and professional growth programs. By investing in their holistic development, colleges can cultivate more loyal alumni, engaged fanbases, and well-rounded individuals who carry their positive experiences into the broader community.
This isn't just about compliance or keeping pace with trends. It's about leadership—recognizing that true success in college athletics isn't solely measured by revenue or media headlines, but by the lasting impact on the lives of student-athletes. When administrators embrace this broader vision, they'll find not just solutions, but sustainable growth and a stronger, more resilient athletic culture.
Thanks again for sparking this important conversation. I'm committed to leading in this space, ensuring that the 98% are not just seen, but truly supported.

postsData.name:
Michael Kainatsky
Michael Kainatsky
postsData.content:
Have humans actually decided that they don't like other humans?


Seriously!

It's a crazy sentiment but it's also one that seems to be more and more accurate by the day.

A.I. is very rapidly replacing the need for human interactions, human employees and human thinking.

Do you actually want this?

It seems that all the new tech is built to make people believe they're dealing with people

when they're actually not.

Can someone tell me why anyone would want to have a bot pretend to be a human

in order to fool actual humans into believing it's human?

Is it in the name of progress, efficiency, profit or just an utter hatred for humans?

Most of the worlds problems are actually interpersonal problems.

Instead of fixing the problem, are we just creating tech to replace interpersonal relationships all together?

How long will it be before no one wants human romantic relationships at all?

Are we all complicit in helping society architect its own demise?

The 6th mass extinction just this time, on purpose?

What is the point of this life if everyone seems to be focused on dehumanizing everything?

Am I just paranoid or do I need to invest in some cats?

Yours truthfully,

comments.commentText:
Wow, that’s an interesting perspective! 

I do wonder if we’re getting to the point where we’ll need to intentionally "unplug" to protect our humanity.

Could be a good reason to get those cats, though—at least they’re 100% real!

postsData.content:
Auto Expo 2025: A Glimpse into the Future of Mobility & Marketing! 

Stepping into Auto Expo 2025 was nothing short of stepping into the future! From groundbreaking electric vehicles (EVs) to tech-driven innovations like autonomous driving, smart connectivity, and sustainability initiatives, the event was a goldmine of inspiration.

One of the biggest takeaways? Marketing isn’t just about selling a product; it’s about selling an experience, a vision, and a future! 

 The Marketing Shift in Automobiles
 EVs as a Lifestyle – Brands like Tata, Maruti Suzuki, MG, and VinFast emphasized sustainability, smart tech, and long-term savings.
 Experiential Marketing – Interactive booths, AR/VR, and immersive experiences replaced static ads—engagement is the new ROI!
 Ola Electric’s Bold Vision – With 4,000 service centers by 2024 and models like the Ola S1 Z, Ola’s D2C and social media-driven strategy is setting new benchmarks.

 Innovations That Blew My Mind!

The event wasn’t just about cars; it was about disrupting mobility as we know it. Some game-changing concepts that could redefine urban living:

 Hospital on Wheels: A mobile healthcare unit equipped with essential medical facilities, bringing emergency care to remote areas.

 Multi-Utility Auto-Rickshaws: EVs that double as charging stations, mini cafés, and even small-scale mobile workspaces—talk about making the most of mobility!

 Café on Wheels: A fusion of transport and leisure, where businesses can operate a mobile café, tapping into the on-the-go consumer mindset.
What are your thoughts on the future of automotive marketing?

comments.commentText: Auto Expo 2025, Witness the future of mobility with cutting edge EVs, experiential marketing, and visionary innovations.

postsData.name:
Kiran Babu
Kiran Babu
postsData.content:
You know that moment in an interview when they ask, “Why are you leaving your current job?”

Yeah… that one. ‍

It always feels like a trap.

If you’re honest, you risk sounding negative about your old job.
If you admit you were overwhelmed, you might seem like you can’t handle pressure.
If you say you’re looking for growth, maybe they’ll think you’re not loyal.

But lying? That’s not a great way to start a new role either.


So what do you even say?

Here’s the thing—this question forces people into a corner. It makes the interview about the past instead of the future.

Imagine asking someone on a first date, “Why did you break up with your ex?”
Exactly. Awkward.


But if you have to answer it, here’s how to:
 Soften the negatives without being fake.
For example, instead of saying, “My boss micromanaged everything,” try “I’m looking for a role where I can take more ownership and grow independently.”

 Shift the focus to the new opportunity.
Talk about what excites you about this job and how it aligns with your goals.

 Keep it positive and authentic. Be pleasant while you answer—it shows you’ve moved on and are focused on the future.


Most people leave jobs for pretty common reasons—lack of growth, bad culture fit, or just wanting something more aligned with their goals.

So instead of digging for red flags, maybe it’s time we focus on where people want to go, not just where they’ve been.

What’s your take? Should we retire this question?

comments.commentText: I agree completely that it’s time to look forward rather than dwelling on the past when hiring talent.
